content.description: Start up a shallow chimney towards an iced up crack (early season or thin conditions). Follow this to the obvious ice above and pull into a small turf alcove with a good stance. Make a few rock moves up towards the trees. A tree 10 feet back from the edge has cord and two rap rings or traverse hard right for 15 feet along the edge to a two bolt anchor above the rock climb "Cinch Sack".When in thin, earlier season shape, the opening 20 feet can be tricky to protect until reaching the fat ice above. Size this one up accordingly and bring hexes, a smattering of rock gear and maybe a specter.
content.location: Just right of the rock climb "Anna's Treat" (lone bolt in a blank face) above the wooden stairs.

climbs.name: Ferret Legger
climbs.fa: Jon Sykes, Chris Marks, Gareth Slattery, 1996

content.description: A delicate, thin smear will sometimes form just right of "Scottish Gully". Two horizontal cracks provide rock protection right off the ground then the bolts of "Cinch Sack" can be clipped or chipped out if covered in ice. At the top of the ice, follow a tree filled crack straight up to a two bolt anchor. One could also traverse left from the top of the ice into the finish of "Scottish Gully".
content.protection: Winter rock rack, bolts and a stubby screw if you're lucky
content.location: Just 10 feet right of Scottish Gully before the metal ladder. Look for two bolts in a steep slab.

content.description: Follows the rock climb of the same name. We were able to climb the route completely on ice starting in the left facing corner between "Carpet Path" and "Sleep in the Dry Spot". Staying on the ice meant substantially run out climbing but less scratches on the rock, something we should all be conscientious of. Belay from the two bolts with chains after making the final moves over the overlap.
content.protection: Winter rock rack, stubbies and a few 13's
content.location: On the Grunge Wall at Echo, roughly 75 feet left of the Amphitheater ice climbs.

content.description:
Echo crag has a high concentration of good single-pitch and mix ice climbs with a short approach. However, afternoon-sun makes ice often thin and vulnerable to hot weather. 

  Be careful not to scrape up the rock-routes.
